passages.text: August 29, 2025 04:30 AM GMT

We update forecasts post results. We note a number of positive moving parts at TMUS (better service revenue growth, recent M&A, DISH spectrum sale, stronger share price). While German competition is intense, we view the reaction to the Q2 results print (- 5%) as excessive. Overweight. Top Pick.

We view the Q2 results reaction as excessive. The - 5% share price reaction (to a non- cash charge) implied a \(> - 15\%\) markdown of Telekom's German Telco business; Q2 saw better revenue growth at TMUS, while M&A is accretive. Shares have rebounded from a low of \(\) 220/\$ (Jun) to \(\) 250/\$ (today), equating to \(\) 2.3/\$ for DT; DT will be a beneficiary of the One Big Beautiful Bill (US tax legislation), given its high US capital intensity ( \(\) 10bn\(pa). We now foresee lower US cash taxes; While Q3 EBITDAal in Germany will be less strong than H1 ( \(52\%\) today (via the share re- purchase program). TMUS remains the largest / most valuable Telco operator in the world (with a market cap of \(\) 280bn\); iv. DT hosted a Capital Markets Day in October 2024. Key management guidance included a 4yr EBITDAal growth target of \(+4\%\) to \(+6\%\) pa (Dec 2023a- 27e), and a 2027e EPS target of ca \(\) 2.50/\$ sh (MSE: \(\) 2.68/\$ sh); v. TMUS recently closed the acquisitions of Lumos, Metronet (both fibre service providers) and US Cellular.

Many positive moving parts at TMUS (MSR, DISH spectrum, M&A, cash taxes) - recent TMUS share price strength (worth \(+\) 3 per DT sh). i. TMUS's Q2 print saw a positive share price reaction (+6%) - driven by accelerating service revenue growth (Q1: \(+5.2\%\) , Q2: \(+6.1\%\) ), and an upgrade to net adds guidance. Indeed, H1 saw OpFCF

generation at TMUS rise by \(+8\%\) YoY. The Q2 print was a relief, following the \(- 11\%\) move upon Q1 results (net adds & churn concerns). We believe that the numerous TMUS growth catalysts - Best Network, FWA, B2B, fiber, more rural areas (40% of POPs, beyond Top100 markets) - remain firmly in place. We forecast MSR growth of \(+6.2\%\) pa (Dec 24a- 27e), while price rises provide upside optionality (TMUS owns Best Network, but has the lowest ARPU of the Big 3); ii. We note this week's \(\) 23bn\(spectrum sale by Ehostar (DISH Wireless) to AT&T - we view this as a net positive for TMUS. While the market was not expecting Boost to disrupt the US wireless industry (despite meaningful investor concerns as recently as 2023 - when TMUS shares fell by\) >10\% - Are US Wireless Wars Set to Intensify?), this transaction signals not only the end of that risk, but the migration of significant spectrum holdings from EchoStar to one of the Big 3; iii. We estimate that the three US acquisitions should boost TMUS' cash earnings by \(>5\%\) ; iv. We note that the TMUS share price has now rebounded by almost \(+15\%\) , from a low of \(\) 220/\$ sh (17 June) to the current level of ca \(\) 250/\$ sh. This higher share price implies an extra \(+\) 15.5bn / \(+\) 3.2 per share of value for DT (assuming a \(52\%\) equity stake, \(\) 1/5\$ of 1165).

Lower cash taxes at TMUS - implies higher FCF for DT AG. As outlined in our recent research - Is Europe Exposed to the One Big Beautiful Bill Act? Aug 2025 - US companies with high R&D or capital expenditure will be among the greatest beneficiaries of the One Big Beautiful Bill. With TMUS spending almost \(\) 10bn\(pa of capex, we expect a tailwind from accelerated depreciation and lower cash taxes. We now expect TMUS cash taxes to total\) \ \(4bn\) by 2028 (vs ca \(\) 5bn\(before).

Why we believe the Q2 results reaction was disproportionate. DT shares fell by - \(5\%\) the day they reported Q2 2025 results (8 August) - this decline was based solely on concerns surrounding German trends (broadband KPIs & domestic EBITDAaL growth). We believe that the - \(5\%\) share price decline was an over- reaction. Why? i. Our model assumes that DT's asset value (target EV) is broken up as follows (roughly) ... US: \(60\%\) , Germany: \(25\%\) , Europe: \(10\%\) , Other: \(5\%\) . Given the stock market reaction was almost certainly solely linked with perceived German weakness, the - \(5\%\) DT share price decline implied a \(>15\%\) write- down of Telekom's German business. ii. We note that the German EBITDAaL miss was based on an accounting technicality - a non- cash profit write- down (both Q1a and Q2a). Stripping out this write- down, we estimate clean German EBITDAaL growth was ca \(+3.5\%\) in Q2a, some \(+60bps\) above consensus expectations. Further / future write- downs are not expected. iii. Q4 German EBITDAaL will be less strong than H1a (

employees today). On the Q1 results call, Group CFO Christian Illek had acted his expectation that declines in the number of employees would accelerate; in Easy comps - annualisation of pay rises & non- cash charges. DT paid its staff \(a + 6\%\) wage increase on 1 October 2024. We estimated this was a ca - 2ppt headwind for EBITDAaL over recent Qtrs, but will annualise it in Q4 2025. Similarly, the non- cash charges announced at Q2 results will also lap in H1 2026, delivering a ca \(+30\) bps and \(+60\) bps boost to EBITDAaL growth, in Q1 and Q2 2026, respectively (the non- cash charge unwinds over 2yrs); iii. Competition. Following peak revenue declines of \(- 6\%\) YoY (registered just 2- 3 Qtrs ago), we forecast Vodafone Germany will now see revenue stabilisation (YoY growth) by calendar Q4 - we believe this milestone, coupled with a need to return to positive EBITDAaL uplift, may encourage the No2 player to limit its recent competitive consumer offerings. Adding up all these elements, we expect DT Germany to deliver ca \(+3.5\%\) EBITDAaL growth in each Qtr, between Q4 2025 and Q3 2026.

What will DT do with its excess FCF? To be announced at Q3 results. As background, DT's 2024 CMD guidance targets 'excess FCF' of €15bn (over 4yrs, 1 Jan 2024 - 31 Dec 2027, Exhibit 6). This distributable cash is after paying its annual dividend (at DT AG), and after completing €4bn of DT AG share buybacks (2024e- 25e). This excess cash can be used for additional DT share buybacks (MS forecasts an average of €2.75bn pa, 2024a- 2027e) or funding an increased equity stake in TMUS. As outlined before, we see the €15bn excess FCF target as potentially conservative (MSE: >€16bn) - given stronger EBITDAaL growth (US & Europe), lower cash taxes and returns on US acquisitions. This begs the question - what will DT say at Q3 results? i. We expect DT to increase its DPS to €1.20 per share (from €0.90/ sh last year, an increase of \(+14\%\) ); ii. Given recent share price weakness, we expect DT to scale up its share buyback, from €2.0bn last year, to €2.5bn this year (leverage is expected to remain near the Group's target of 2.75x, so flexibility is limited); iii. We believe DT will seek to continue slowly increase its TMUS stake beyond 52%, via partial participation in the US re- purchase program.

Has the Euro Telco sector debate moved on, beyond DT? Yes and No - DT also has exposure to M&A. DT was unquestionably the European Telco sector success story of 2024 and early 2025 (TMUS and DT AG CMDs, strong share price increase propelled DT to being a Top10 European corporate, all sectors, by market cap). However, DT shares have under- performed since the end of February. Telco stocks with greater exposure to consolidation (in France, Spain & Italy) - or cost cutting equity stories - have since out- performed (and quite meaningfully too). With Italian consolidation discussions now on- hold (Source: Iliad, Q2 call, 28 Aug), investor attention may switch back to DT. Conversely, we would also argue that while Telekom has less upside potential from consolidation, the German incumbent does enjoy some exposure: i. DT could benefit from hypothetical German Telco consolidation (25% of EV); ii. The consolidation of the three US acquisitions will accrete DT's cash earnings by ca \(+4\%\) - as retail revenue/EBITDA are consolidated, but fiber capex is off- Balance Sheet (at the JV); iii. DT could also lead consolidation efforts in its European portfolio (many Central & Eastern European markets have four Telco players), while the Group owns \(>20K\) towers / sites across Europe, outside of Germany (as precedent - Telekom monetised a 51% stake in its German / Austrian towers for ca 25x EBITDAaL).

DT shares have generated a positive return of \(+13\%\) this year (including €0.90/sh of dividend, paid in April).
However, the Bonn- based Telco's shares have under- performed both the European Telco Index (SXKP), and the local / German DAX 30 benchmark, by - Sppts and - 8ppts, respectively.
Exhibit 1: DT shares have generated a double- digit- % return (YTD, incl dividend), but have under- performed a strong European Telco sector performance
Perhaps equally interestingly, after a strong start to 2025 (shares \(+20\%\) over first 8 weeks of the year), DT shares have seen pretty sustained weakness over the past 6m months, driven by:

- US\$ weakness, with the US currency declining \(-15\%\) peak-to-trough (vs the €) 
- this represented a \(-9\%\) headwind for DT, given the US is ca \(60\%\) of projected 2027e earnings;- A weaker TMUS share price (from a peak of \$273 to a low of \$220/sh) 
- including an \(-11\%\) share price decline post-Q1 results;- Increased German Telco competition (fixed & mobile industries);- Profit-taking on DT shares 
- including investors switching (increasing focus on stocks exposed to European Telco consolidation).
Exhibit 2: DT shares returned \(+20\%\) in the first 8 weeks of this year - but have underperformed for the past 6 months
We update our forecasts to reflect:

- Q2 results at both DT AG and TMUS (and associated guidance upgrades);- The inclusion / first-time consolidation of both Metronet and Lumos (US fiber service providers);- Cash tax benefits at TMUS - from The One Big Beautiful Bill (as per our research Is Europe Exposed to the One Big Beautiful Bill Act? August 2025);- Slight further US\$ weakness (vs the €) - our €/US\$ forecasts changes from 1.155 to 1.165 (weaker \$, a further headwind for DT).
In terms of key changes:

- Our Group turnover (2025e-28e, on average) rises +0.5%, driven by the inclusion of Metronet and Lumos. Underlying forecasts fall very marginally (German equipment);- US EBITDA forecasts also rise by +0.5% - following stronger-than-expected Q2 profitability and the inclusion of the two US fiber acquisitions. Meanwhile, our German EBITDAAL outlook is -40bps weaker, driven by Q2 2025 weakness. However, as this was a non-cash charge, the Q2 miss is somewhat offset by easy comps next year. Our ex-US EBITDAAL forecasts are unchanged (although they do fall -40bps this year);- Our Group capex and OpFCF outlook is unchanged;- Last, our ECFC forecasts rise by +2% (lower cash taxes), while EPS falls by -3% (higher P&L taxes).

We consolidate the two US fiber business for the first time. In terms of key considerations:
·TMUS will consolidate the revenues and EBITDA from the FiberCos' retail businesses. We assume $3.6bn of fiber revenues by 2030 (just 3% of the total turnover pie / 4% of service revenues);
·On the flipside, capex from the businesses will be on an off-Balance Sheet basis (not consolidated by TMUS);
·Our previous research has highlighted how we expect the consolidation of the three businesses would accrete TMUS cash earnings by ca +6% (and therefore DT
AG earnings by ca \(+4\%\)
Our Sum- of- the- Parts valuation remains the primary driver of our Target Price for Deutsche Telekom AG. This valuation remains unchanged (at €40 per share).
In terms of key changes:

Our TMUS share price rises from \(\) 180\(/sh to\) \ \(185 / sh\) (increases our DT AG valuation by ca \(+1.7\%\) , ceteris aribus); A slightly weaker US \(\) negatively impacts our DT valuation by just ca \(- 0.5\%\) (a \(- 0.9\%\) currency downgrade x \(60\%\) weighting of TMUS within the DT AG pie); We raise our T- Systems valuation by ca \(+\) 2bn \((+\) 0.4 per DT share), reflecting new opportunities in the Defence sector (as per our research Ripple Effects: Telcos & Defence Spending - Aug 2025) and sovereign Cloud; Our German valuation is largely unchanged ( \(\) 85bn\(, an implied 7.6x EBITDAaL); We have rolled forward our Target Price date, by 6mths, from December 2025 to June 2026.
